questions.prompt: The DC component X₀ of a square pulse train with amplitude 1, width 2T₁, and period T₀ is:
questions.explanation: X₀ = (1/T₀)∫_{-T₁}^{+T₁} 1 dt = 2T₁/T₀. This is simply the duty cycle — the fraction of the period during which the pulse is 'on'. For example, a 50% duty cycle gives X₀ = 0.5.

questions.prompt: The general FS coefficient X_k of the square pulse train (for k ≠ 0) is:
questions.explanation: X_k = sin(kω₀T₁)/(kπ). This comes from evaluating the FS integral: integrating e^{-jkω₀t} over [-T₁, +T₁], using Euler's formula to recognise sin, and simplifying with ω₀T₀ = 2π.

questions.prompt: Why are all X_k real for the centred square pulse train?
options: A) Because the signal is periodic
B) Because the signal is real and even: x(t) = x(-t)
D) Because k ranges from -∞ to +∞
questions.explanation: A real, even signal has real FS coefficients. The centred square pulse is symmetric about t=0, so x(t) = x(-t). This even symmetry ensures that the imaginary parts cancel in the FS integral, leaving purely real X_k values.

questions.prompt: If the pulse width 2T₁ is halved while T₀ stays the same, the main lobe of the spectrum:
questions.explanation: The main lobe width is inversely proportional to T₁. Halving the pulse width doubles the spectral width — narrower pulses require higher-frequency components to represent the sharper transitions. This is the fundamental bandwidth-duration trade-off.

questions.prompt: The X_k of the square pulse train decay as:
questions.explanation: The sinc envelope decays as 1/(kπ), which is a 1/k rate. This relatively slow decay is due to the sharp discontinuities in the square pulse. Smoother signals (like triangular waves) have faster decay rates (1/k²).

questions.prompt: For a square pulse with T₀ = 4, 2T₁ = 1, the value of X₀ is:
questions.explanation: X₀ = 2T₁/T₀ = 1/4 = 0.25. The pulse is on for 1 out of every 4 seconds, giving a 25% duty cycle. This is the average value of the signal.

questions.prompt: Zero crossings of the spectrum X_k occur when:
options: B) kω₀T₁ = nπ for non-zero integer n
questions.explanation: X_k = sin(kω₀T₁)/(kπ) = 0 when sin(kω₀T₁) = 0, i.e., when kω₀T₁ = nπ for integer n ≠ 0. These zeros define the lobes of the sinc envelope.

questions.prompt: The FS at a discontinuity of x(t) converges to:
options: C) The average of left- and right-hand limits
questions.explanation: At a jump discontinuity, the FS converges to the midpoint (arithmetic mean) of the left and right limits. For the square pulse jumping from 0 to 1, the FS converges to 0.5 at the discontinuity.

questions.prompt: In the equation x(t) = Σ_{m} g(t - mT₀), the summation creates:
options: B) A periodic extension of the pulse g(t)
C) The Fourier Transform of g(t)
D) The convolution of g(t) with itself
questions.explanation: Shifting g(t) by integer multiples of T₀ and summing creates an infinite periodic repetition — the periodic extension. This is the standard way to define a periodic signal from a single-period template.

questions.prompt: The bandwidth-duration principle for the square pulse says:
options: A) Narrow pulses have narrow spectra
B) Narrow pulses have wide spectra
C) All pulses have the same bandwidth
D) Bandwidth is independent of pulse shape
questions.explanation: Narrow pulses (small T₁) produce wide spectra (many significant harmonics). This is the fundamental bandwidth-duration trade-off: to represent sharp time-domain features, you need many high-frequency components.
